mnemonic: A giant apple (symbolizing New York City) juggling 789 miniature bridges and tunnels, including mini versions of the Brooklyn Bridge and Manhattan Bridge, plus a set of 24 small bridges that are literally moving around like characters in a cartoon, all with a sign that proudly exclaims "No Tolls!"
fact: - NYC DOT owns, operates, and maintains 789 bridges and tunnels in New York, including famous bridges such as the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges, and 24 movable bridges, all of which have no tolls.

mnemonic: A cartoon construction crew of belts tightening up structures while a calendar showing the year 2009 hovers above and a set of six bridge-shaped cookies with icing depicting "Bay Ridge Avenue," "Gerritsen Inlet," "Mill Basin," "Paerdegat Basin," "Rockaway Parkway," and "Fresh Creek Basin" are laid out, each with a tiny '1939' candle that is being blown out by a character representing time.
fact: - The Belt Parkway Bridges Reconstruction project began in 2009 to replace six original structures from 1939 that have outlived their usefulness; this includes bridges over Bay Ridge Avenue, Gerritsen Inlet, Mill Basin, Paerdegat Basin, Rockaway Parkway, and Fresh Creek Basin.

mnemonic: An animated digital map of Brooklyn where a queen bee is leading a construction crew of express ants with little hard hats. They are working diligently on a stretch of honeycomb that resembles a highway, repairing honey drips and replacing beeswax cells. The honeycomb highway spans over 21 toothpick bridges while a quirky triple-layered cake with cantilever icing decorations stands proud in the background. The entire insect crew buzzes about, emphasizing the importance of maintaining their vital nectar flow linkage.
fact: - The Brooklyn-Queens Expressway (BQE) project involves rehabilitation or replacement of 1.5 miles of the highway in Brooklyn, impacting 21 bridges and a unique triple-cantilever structure; the project aims to maintain this vital interstate link.

mnemonic: Create an energetic chef named Ed Cook, bustling around a kitchen located on the bustling Queens-body Road Bridge, juggling exactly 178 toy cars while simultaneously frying up a breakfast for the year "2010 eggs". Around him, ten famous New York City bridges, including the Brooklyn Bridge and Manhattan Bridge, with landmark status ribbons, are animatedly discussing their historical significance. In the background, a comic book-style flashback panel shows a bridge wearing a crown, waving goodbye to symbolize the demolition of King's Bridge in 1917, while the Brooklyn Bridge, sporting a long, wise beard and carrying a walking stick marked "1883," proudly stands as the oldest bridge still in the traffic game.
fact: - The Ed Koch Queensboro Bridge is the busiest NYC DOT bridge with 178,000 vehicles crossing on an average weekday in 2010, and ten New York City bridges have landmark status, with seven under DOT jurisdiction, including the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges; the city's first bridge, the King's Bridge built in 1693, was demolished in 1917, while the oldest currently open to traffic is the Brooklyn Bridge from 1883.
